review_title: Lovely people to work with and support but Management and Recruitment could do better
pros: The people I support and supported are all absolutely amazing, as well as the teams I am working with. Everyone very nice, it's a lovely environment to work in, loads of fun. Amazing learning opportunities and really good training programs.
cons:
Management and Recruitment are not responsive of the needs of employees. I was initially put by management on a service that based on my Occupational Health assessed during recruitment I should not have been put on in the first place and this caused a damage on myself, the work performance and the services I was working with. I had to bring it up several times before it got taken seriously and share my very private situation which also made me feel uncomfortable and very stressed. Clearly some people don't know what they are doing or understand the broad spectrum of disabilities, sort of a hypocrisy considering we work protecting  and supporting people with disabilities but there is no support provided for employees who have disabilities themselves. 

Great support from the Team Facilitators. However, there is a different treatment to when you first start and when you have been working for over the 6 months probation. You have to create your own work life balance because shift life can be exhausting and being assertive of your own needs is fundamental otherwise you get put on very illegal working hours shifts.

review_title: Such a shame the way this company is run
pros: A lot of the staff - carers and office staff are lovely and so dedicated to their work. You meet a variety of people and make a difference to peoples lives. Peter Scott was chief Exec when I was there and I cannot praise him enough - he genuinely cared and was a great boss. Its unfortunate we also had to deal with a Director on a daily basis who was pretty much a tyrant.
cons:
The current Chief Executive was a Director when I was there and there is a strategy of intimidation, bullying and quite honestly a toxic environment. I watched many colleagues get 'thrown under the bus'. 5 Head's of HR were in post in the three years I was there and they either left or were sacked cause they wouldn't jump as high as she commanded. 
I don't believe that management has an interest in the concerns of those with learning disabilities and their families unfortunately. The company is actually a charity and a business - the business and the way it is run is the worst. 

People are overworked and underpaid - unless you threaten to leave and they realise they cant do without you and then they throw £5k and a car at you. If your seen as 'a little person' they could not care less. 

My mental health suffered greatly by working there. For an awful salary - that never increased, zero support, and a dreaded feeling of every single day wondering if I was going to be sacked.

review_title: The most fulfilling job I’ve had
pros:
As a PA with ENABLE Scotland I can honestly say it’s the most fulfilling job I’ve ever had. 

I genuinely believe in the work they do and I have seen first hand the difference it makes to the people life’s I support through ENABLE Scotland. 

I can’t imagine ever finding another position as rewarding as the one I’m in at the moment or finding another team that offers as much support as mines does. 

Everyone I have worked with in my years as a PA have only ever had the best interest of the individuals we support and I believe that lies at the heart of the charity.

The amount of pride I have in my role and appreciation for the dedicated work everyone does for these young individuals is immeasurable
cons: Depending on shifts transport may be an issue if you don’t drive, if you are on an early or late shift!
